means: <正>为（所犯罪过）接受惩罚，赎（罪）

sentence.Network_en: He had a chance to confess and expiate his guilt.
sentence.Network_cn: 他有认错和赎罪的机会。

sentence.Network_en: Even death would not expiate all his crimes.
Now I was to expiate all my offences at the gallows.
sentence.Network_cn: 现在我将在绞刑架上赎我一切的罪过.

derivation.yuyuan_name: late 16th cent. (in the sense 'end (rage, sorrow, etc.) by suffering it to the full'): from Latin expiat- 'appeased by sacrifice', from the verb expiare, from ex- 'out' + piare (from pius 'pious')

entry.def: If you expiate guilty feelings or bad behaviour, you do something to indicate that you are sorry for what you have done.

example.ex: It seemed that Alice was expiating her father's sins with her charity work.
example.tran: 似乎艾丽斯正在通过自己的慈善工作来弥补父亲的罪过。

auth_sentence.content: My strong guess is that he doesn't think he has anything to expiate.

auth_sentence.res_content_con: My strong guess is that he doesn't think he has anything to expiate.

auth_sentence.content: Presumably, this was a means for Spinelli to expiate his drumming sins, arranged between Tata and him.

auth_sentence.content: Order as principle, beauty as salvation: words, too, can push back the chaos within and help us expiate our sins.
